anomalies.message: [REJECT] Written amount contains spelling errors indicating document alteration.
Spelling errors in written amount (“FOUN” vs FOUR, “FISTY” vs FIFTY”)

raw_text:
MoneyGram
PAY TO: SARAH CHEN
MONEYGRAMⓇ
MONEY ORDER
9021056789
AMOUNT:
$450.00
DATE:
OCTOBER 26, 2024
FOUN HUNDRED FISTY AND 00//100 DOLLARS
FROM: MICHAEL LEE
456 PINE ST, ANYTOWN, CA 91234
9835647821
Michael Lee
AGENT AUTHORIZED SIGNATURE

ai_analysis.summary: Written amount contains spelling errors indicating document alteration.
reasoning: Raw OCR text shows “FOUN HUNDRED FISTY AND 00//100 DOLLARS,” with “FOUN” and “FISTY” misspelled, a strong sign of tampering.
Training data indicates 45% of fraud cases involve amount mismatches or alterations.
ML model scored this case as low risk, but spelling errors in a professionally printed field override ML assessment per policy.
No other anomalies (issuer valid, serial format correct, signature present), but amount alteration is concrete evidence.
key_indicators: Spelling errors in written amount (“FOUN” vs FOUR, “FISTY” vs FIFTY”)
actionable_recommendations: Reject the money order and request purchaser to obtain a new, correctly printed money order.
Verify purchaser ID and have them complete a new transaction under supervision.
Contact MoneyGram to confirm serial number and issuance details.

reasons: Raw OCR text shows “FOUN HUNDRED FISTY…” instead of “FOUR HUNDRED FIFTY,” indicating manual or counterfeit alteration.
Numeric amount ($450.00) does not align with the misspelled written amount line, violating exact amount match integrity.

ai_analysis.training_insights: High correlation in our dataset between written amount anomalies and confirmed fraud (45% of cases), reinforcing the decision.
ai_analysis.historical_comparison: No identical past cases, but similar spelling-error cases were consistently confirmed as tampered and rejected.
